The wide band gap of ceria limited the light absorption and photothermal conversion of copper-ceria catalyst for photothermal preferential oxidation of CO (CO-PROX). In the present work, doping Bi element was adopted to regulate the energy band and catalytic performance of CuCeO2−x nanorod catalysts for photothermal CO-PROX. Bi/CuCeO2−x nanorods were synthesized by co-precipitation hydrothermal and deposition precipitation method. The Bi/CuCeO2−x catalyst with the molar ratio of Bi/Ce 2.5% exhibited the best catalytic performance and the CO conversion reached 90% under 2.5 suns with a surface temperature of 120 °C. The doped Bi species were incorporated into the CeO2 lattice and promoted the formation of oxygen vacancy sites and the strong Cu-Ce interaction, as revealed by XRD, XPS, Raman and H2-TPR results. In addition, doping Bi reduced the band gap of ceria nanorod from 2.77 to 2.47 eV and remarkably enhanced the UV–vis light response and photogenerated carrier separation of Bi/CuCeO2−x-2.5. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Preferential oxidation of CO Photothermal CuCeO2−x nanorod catalyst Bi dopant Oxygen vacancy Data Availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Proton Exchange Membrane Fuel Cell (PEMFC) possesses the strengths of high energy density, mild working temperature, wide scope in the application, and meets the continuous needs of energy used in production and life [1]. Currently, the industrial H2 stream is mostly derived from the hydrocarbon reforming reaction. However, 0.3%− 1% CO is mixed in the produced hydrogen-rich stream due to the thermodynamic equilibrium. Pt-based electrodes of PEMFC can be poisoned by even a trace amount of CO, which shortens the service life [2]. CO preferential oxidation (CO-PROX) is an effective means to reduce CO content in hydrogen-rich hydrogen below 100 ppm. The ceria-based catalyst is a kind of promising candidates for highly efficient CO-PROX process. It is mainly due to that the unique electronic structure of rare earth cerium element ([Ce]−4 f15d16 s2) leads to its strong oxidation-reduction ability. The oxidation-reduction cycle behavior of cerium is based on the reversible transformation between Ce3+ and Ce4+, which leads to the change of oxygen coordination of cerium ions and the formation of oxygen vacancy in the CeO2 crystal lattice [3]. Marino et al. [4] compared the CO-PROX performances of Pt, Pd, and Ir-supported CeO2 catalysts. The experimental results showed that Pt-supported CeO2 nanocatalyst had the best performance, because Pt could form a strong interaction with CeO2, which significantly improved the CO-PROX activity of the Pt catalyst. Although Pt-based metal catalysts have good catalytic activity in CO oxidation reactions, the cost of platinum-based catalysts is too high and the resources are limited. In recent years, the CuO-CeO2 catalyst has attracted extensive attention in CO-PROX on account of its unusual oxygen storage capacity, excellent reducibility, and sufficient sites to support copper [5–7]. Wang et al. [8] used the urea grinding method to prepare CuO-CeO2, which revealed high catalytic performance and stability with a wider temperature window of 50 ℃ due to the more active sites and the synergistic effect between highly dispersed copper species and CeO2. Guo et al. [9–12] reported that CuO/CeO2-rod had superior catalytic performance, lower T50%, and a wider temperature window than CuO/CeO2-plate and CuO/CeO2-cube. In addition, Zhao et al. [13] found that doping Sn promotes the Cu-Ce catalyst to CO-PROX in the rich hydrogen, but the chlorine ion in the reaction process inhibited the CO-PROX activity of the catalyst in CO-PROX in the low-temperature range. The traditional thermal catalytic process costs lots of energy input which is difficult to be carried out at room temperature and often requires noble metals [14]. Simulated sunlight has been proposed to replace the thermal energy to drive the CO oxidation reaction. Dai et al. [15] prepared Cu-modified Au-TiO2 catalyst for photocatalytic oxidation of CO. It is reported that the CuO shell generates photoexcitation under visible light irradiation, enhances the electron transfer between Au and increases the carrier surface electron density, which notably accelerates the adsorption and activation of CO and O2. However, the photocatalytic process is limited by low light utilization efficiency and cannot fully utilize solar energy resources [16]. Recent researches [17,18] have confirmed that the photothermal catalytic reaction, which simultaneously utilizes the light and the heat derived from the sun, is promising to facilitate the catalytic reaction and overcome the deficiency of a single catalytic process. Zhu et al. [19] reported a Fe3Si assisted Co3O4 rhombus-shaped nanorods catalysts for efficient photothermal CO oxidation under solar irradiation, which can convert 0.3–0.35 kW·m−2 solar irradiation into a temperature as high as 160 °C that able to excite the activity of Co3O4 nanorods for complete CO oxidation. CeO2 has been widely used in both thermal catalytic and photocatalytic oxidation reactions [20], which is a promising candidate for the photothermal catalytic process [21]. Ma et al. [22] developed a MOF crystal engineering method to controllably synthesize a copper-ceria catalyst. They found that the well-dispersed photoactive Cu-[O]-Ce species make the catalyst remarkably efficient and stable in photothermal preferential oxidation of CO. They concluded that the coexistence of photochemistry and thermochemistry effects contributes to the high efficiency. Recently, our group [23] studied solar-driven photothermal CO-PROX on the CuCeO2−x nanorod catalysts synthesized by fast coprecipitation at room temperature. It is concluded that the catalytic activity for photothermal CO-PROX is both affected by the photo-to-thermal conversion and Cu-Ce synergy interaction, and the optimal copper dopant with weight content of Cu/(CuO+CeO2) of 10 wt% promotes visible light absorption and redox property of ceria. However, due to the wide band gap of ceria (∼3.2 eV), the light absorption is limited to the UV band with weak visible light, which leads to the insufficient light absorption and relatively low light-to-thermal conversion efficiency of ceria based photothermal catalysts. Bi2O3-based materials have received widespread concern because of their excellent optical and electrical properties, for example, a suitable energy gap, high refractive index, and excellent dielectric properties [24,25]. The electrons on the valence band (VB) of the Bi2O3 semiconductor photocatalyst are excited by light and transited to the conduction band (CB). After the electrons transition, holes with strong oxidation are left on the valence band [26]. Therefore, Bi2O3 is a desirable visible light-responsive semiconductor photocatalyst, which shows a rapid light response speed and high solar light utilization under sunlight [27,28]. In addition, Bi-doped suitable elements can expand the wavelength range of light absorption and improve the photocatalytic performance [29,30]. Zhang et al. [31] prepared Bi-doped ms-TiO2 photocatalyst that highly responsive to visible light. The spectral response was extended from UV to the visible region by Bi doping, and electron-hole recombination was significantly reduced. For the purpose to optimize the structure and properties of CuCeO2−x nanorod catalysts, Bi doping was chosen to regulate the oxygen vacancy concentration and photo-absorption capacity of CuCeO2−x nanorod catalysts. A set of Bi-doped CeO2 catalysts was prepared by the co-precipitation hydrothermal method and CuO was supported on Bi/CeO2−x nanorod by the precipitation-deposition method. XRD, HRTEM, N2-physysorption @ −196 °C, H2-TPR, O2-TPD, UV-Vis-IR, photoluminescence spectrum (PL), ICP, Raman and XPS were used to analyze the influence of Bi dopant amount on the structure and texture property, redox property, optical property and catalytic performance of the Bi/CuCeO2−x nanorod catalysts for photothermal CO-PROX. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Chemicals and materials All reagents utilized were AR analytical grade reagents obtained from Shanghai Macklin Biochemical Technology Co., LTD. These reagents of Ce(NO3)3·6 H2O (99.99%), Cu(NO3)2·3 H2O (98%), Bi(NO3)3·5 H2O (99%), NaOH (97%), Concentrated nitric acid and anhydrous ethanol were used without further purification. The solutions used in the experiment were all prepared using deionized water. 2.2 Preparation of Bi-doped CeO2 (Bi/CeO2−x) nanorod supports Bi-doped CeO2 supports and Bi2O3 samples were synthesized by the co-precipitation hydrothermal method. At room temperature, 4 mmol of Ce(NO3)3·6 H2O and Bi(NO3)3·5 H2O with the molar ratios of Bi/Ce of 0, 1%, 2.5%, 5% and 7.5% (the mole of Bi(NO3)3·5 H2O are 0, 0.04, 0.1, 0.2 and 0.3 mmol, respectively) were mixed in 5 mL of HNO3 solution. Under magnetic stirring, the mixed solution was dripped to 70 mL of NaOH solution of 8 mol/L, and the mixture was stirred for another 0.5 h to form a colloidal suspension. Subsequently, the suspension was decanted into a stainless-steel autoclave, which was put in a drying oven at 100 ℃ for 24 h[11]. After cooling naturally, the precipitate was centrifugalized and cleaned with deionized water and absolute ethanol by turns. At last, the precipitate was dried overnight in a drying oven at 60 °C. The series of Bi-doped CeO2 nanorod supports were labeled as CeO2, Bi/CeO2−x-1, Bi/CeO2−x-2.5, Bi/CeO2−x-5 and Bi/CeO2−x-7.5, respectively with the molar ratios of Bi/Ce of 0, 1%, 2.5%, 5% and 7.5%. The Bi2O3 samples was synthesized by the co-precipitation hydrothermal method as well. 4 mmol of Bi(NO3)3·5 H2O was dissolved in 10 mL of deionized water, then treated at the same condition, the catalyst was labeled as Bi2O3. 2.3 Loading of CuO on Bi/CeO2−x nanorod supports CuO was loaded on Bi/CeO2−x nanorod supports by the deposition-precipitation method. 0.5 g of Bi/CeO2−x nanorods supports were dispersed in 60 mL deionized water and a certain amount of Cu(NO3)2·3 H2O was added in the solution under magnetic stirring. Then the pH of the suspension was regulated to 8–10 by NaOH solution. After aging for 0.5 h, the precipitate was centrifugalized, dried overnight in a vacuum drying oven at 80 ℃, and finally calcined at a temperature of 500 °C for 2 h, the temperature ramp was 5 °C/min from the ambient temperature to 500 °C [11,32]. The obtained Bi-doped CuCeO2−x nanorod catalyst were labeled as CuCeO2−x, Bi/CuCeO2−x-1, Bi/CuCeO2−x-2.5, Bi/CuCeO2−x-5, and Bi/CuCeO2−x-7.5, respectively. The weight fraction of Cu in the catalyst was fixed at 10 w.t %. 2.4 Catalyst characterization The XRD diffractograms were operated to characterize the crystal phase structure and composition of the catalyst. The experimental apparatus was a Bruker D2 PHASER X-ray diffractometer from Germany. The ground powder sample was placed in a quartz sample holder for testing, under the 40 kV tube voltage and 40 mA tube current. The used excitation light source was Ni-filtered Cu Kα1 ray, the scanning speed was 4°/min and the scanning range was 20–100°(2θ). The Maud software was used to Rietveld refine the XRD diffractograms. The anisotropic size function and Popa rules that ascribed the broadening of the crystallite size to a linear combination of spherical harmonic functions were used to refine crystallite size and morphology [10,33]. The HRTEM images were used to study the morphologies, crystal size and Bi dopant distribution of the catalyst, and were conducted on the FEI Tecnai G2 F20 transmission electron microscope with 200 kV working voltage. A moderate amount of Bi/CuCeO2−x-2.5 catalyst was dissolved in absolute ethanol, and the mixture was dropwise onto the copper mesh. After drying naturally, the copper mesh with the catalyst was placed in the TEM sample holder. EDX elemental distribution mapping were characterized by FEI Talos F200S transmission electron microscope. The sample was loaded with molybdenum mesh, and the other preparation details were consistent with HRTEM. The N2 adsorption and desorption isotherm curves of the samples were measured using a TriStar II 3020 (Micromeritics Inc.) automatic physicochemical adsorption instrument at liquid nitrogen temperature (−196 ℃). The samples were pretreated at 200 ℃ in a high vacuum environment for 4 h. The specific surface area of the sample is calculated using the Barrett Emmett Teller (BET) formula, and the pore volume and pore size distribution are calculated using the Barrett Joyner Helenda (BJH) model. The Raman spectra of the catalysts were detected by a HORIBA Scientific LabRAM HR Evolution. The excitation wavelength was 514 nm, the excitation power was 5 mV and the scanning range was 100–2500 cm−1 and repeated three times. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) can be utilized for qualitative and semi-quantitative analyses. The details of the sample surface element composition, chemical state and concentration can be acquired from the peak position, shape and strength of the XPS spectrum. The temperature-programmed hydrogen reduction test (H2-TPR) was performed in a self-made quartz U-shaped tube, which was attached to the TCD detector to detect the concentration of H2 online. 50 mg of the sample with a particle size of 60–80 mesh was pretreated at 300 ℃ for half an hour under a nitrogen atmosphere. After cooling naturally, the N2 gas was shifted to 5% H2/Ar mixed gas with a flow velocity of 40 mL/min, and the temperature-programmed rate was 10 ℃/min from 30 ℃ to 400 ℃. Temperature-programmed desorption of oxygen (O2-TPD) profiles were performed in the self-made devices. The 100 mg sample with a 60–80 mesh particle size was pretreated at 300 ℃ for 0.5 h under pure He gas (40 mL/min). After cooling to 50 ℃, 20% O2/Ar (30 mL/min) was inlet to adsorb oxygen species at 50 ℃ for 1 h. Then, pure He (40 mL/min) was used to remove the excess O2 for 0.5 h. O2 desorption profiles were obtained by heating the catalyst from 50 ℃ to 700 ℃ at 10 ℃/min. The UV–vis-IR absorption of the samples was characterized by the UV-3600 PLUS at room temperature. The scanning speed was medium and the scanning range was 200–2500 nm. The transient photocurrent curves conducted on a CH660E electrochemical workstation. The sample was spin-coated in the FTO conductive glass to prepare the working electrode. Then a standard three-electrode system was used to complete the transient photocurrent test. The electrolyte was Na2SO4 solution (0.5 M), the reference electrode was Ag/AgCl, and the counter electrode was a 1 cm * 1 cm platinum sheet electrode. The light source was a xenon lamp, and the light intensity was adjusted to 250 mW/cm2. The photocurrent test was performed at an interval of 20 s The Photoluminescence spectrum (PL) is used to study charge transitions related to defects and evaluate the separation and recombination characteristics of photogenerated carriers in the samples. The experimental apparatus was Edinburgh FLS1000, UK. The excitation light wavelength was 330 nm, the emission light wavelength changed from 350 nm to 700 nm and the step was 1 nm. Inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectrometer (ICP-OES) is an analytical instrument to determine the content of specific elements in samples. The principle of ICP-OES measurement is based on the fact that atoms and ions will absorb energy to make the contained electrons jump to the excited state and when the excited atoms return to the low energy level, the specific wavelength light is emitted. In ICP-OES, the experimental apparatus was Agilent 7800(MS), US, and the source of energy is the heat of argon plasma working at 10000 K. 2.5 Catalyst performance The photothermal catalytic performance of the catalysts was tested on a self-made cylindrical quartz gas-solid reactor (QR, height 65 mm, diameter 40 mm) with a quartz window of the diameter of 40 mm. 100 mg catalysts were uniformly dispersed on the porous quartz sand substrate with the diameter of 40 mm. The photothermal reaction temperature was monitored by contacting the catalyst surface with a thermocouple, and there was no external heating source during the test. The light illumination is obtained by a 300 W Xenon lamp and the light intensity was adjusted by the height of the light source and measured by CEL-NP2000 optical power meter. The feed gas with a total flow velocity of 100 mL/min and the mixture containing of 25% H2 + 0.5% O2 + 0.5% CO and Ar in balance entered the reaction device [22]. The outlet gas first passed through a cold trap to get rid of the water and the concentration was determined by GC1690 gas chromatography. A carbon molecular sieve (TDX-01) column was adopted to divide CO and CO2 in the outlet gas, and the separated CO and O2 were then converted to methane by virtue of a methanator, whose contents were finally determined by a FID detector with Ar (highly purified, 99.999%) as carrier gas and a limit of less than 3 ppm. H2 and O2 were detected by a TCD detector. The long term photothermocatalytic stability of Bi/CuCeO2−x-2.5 was tested at 250 mW·cm−2, and the feed gas was 25% H2 + 0.5% O2 + 0.5% CO and Ar in balance with a total flow velocity of 100 mL/min. The photothermal CO preferential oxidation catalytic performance for different oxygen and CO concentrations ((1%CO/0.5%O2/25%H2 +Ar, 0.5%CO/1%O2/25%H2 +Ar) was tested at 250 mW·cm−2, and the water resistance of the catalyst was tested at the 7.5 vol% H2O in the reaction gas of 0.5%CO/0.5%O2/25%H2 +Ar at 250 mW·cm−2. The addition of water vapor is achieved by bubbling the reaction gas, and the water vapor content is controlled by changing the water temperature to adjust its saturated vapor pressure. The CO conversion rate was obtained by the formula (CO in represented the CO content in the feed gas, CO out represented the CO content in the tail gas, O2 in represented the O2 content in the feed gas, and O2 out represented the O2 content in the tail gas): CO conversion = （ CO in − CO out ） / CO in × 100 % O 2 selectivity = 0.5 ( CO in − CO out ) / ( O 2 in − O 2 out ） × 100 ( % ) 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Structural properties of catalysts Fig. 1(a-b) presents the HRTEM images of the Bi-CuCeO2−x-2.5 nanorod catalyst. As Fig. 1(a-b) shows, the catalyst has an obvious nanorod morphology with a diameter of about 8–11 nm and a length distribution of 55–140 nm. Bi/CuCeO2−x-2.5 mainly exposes {111} crystal planes of ceria with the lattice spacing of 0.32 nm. EDS-Mapping images of Bi/CuCeO2−x-2.5 catalyst was performed to identify the high dispersion of Bi species in ceria species. As shown in Fig. S4, the signals of Bi, Ce and Cu elements are evenly distributed on EDS mapping images of the Bi/CuCeO2−x-2.5 catalyst without any aggregation, which indicates that Bi element is highly dispersed in the nanorod catalyst. To explore the effect of Bi dopant amount on the microstructure of CuCeO2−x nanorod catalysts, Fig. 1(c) displays the XRD diffractograms of CuCeO2−x nanorod catalysts with different Bi dopant amounts. The XRD diffractograms show the diffraction peaks at 28.5°, 33.1°, 47.5° and 56.4°, which are respectively attributed to the characteristic diffraction peaks of (111), (200), (220) and (311) crystal planes of cubic fluorite CeO2. In addition, the diffraction peaks at 35.6° and 38.7° are attributed to the characteristic diffraction peaks of crystal phase CuO that are caused by the agglomeration of copper oxide species on the surface of ceria nanorods. There are no diffraction peaks of crystal phase bismuth oxide species can be detected, indicating that the highly dispersion of Bi species on the surface or in the lattice of ceria form a solid solution structure. The Bi contents of series Bi/CuCeO2−x nanorod catalysts was confirmed by ICP-OES, which are 1.2%, 2.9%, 4.7% and 6.5% respectively for Bi/CuCeO2−x-1, Bi/CuCeO2−x-2.5, Bi/CuCeO2−x-5 and Bi/CuCeO2−x-7.5. Furthermore, the diffraction peak positions of the series Bi/CuCeO2−x catalysts are also observed in details. It is obvious that all peaks of ceria in the Bi doped samples present a negative shift compared with the undoped CuCeO2−x catalyst, which indicates that the Bi3+ was incorporated in the CeO2 lattice during the preparation process. The XRD patterns of the series catalysts were refined by Rietveld using Maud software. The refined XRD patterns are shown in Fig. S1 and the structural parameters of each catalyst are shown in Table 1. On one hand, the lower contents of bulk phase CuO in Bi/CuCeO2−x-2.5 and Bi/CuCeO2−x-5 demonstrate that appropriate Bi doping could enhance high dispersion of CuOx species on the nanorod support, which is beneficial to their catalytic activity for CO-PROX reaction. On the other hand, the lattice parameters of all the Bi-doped samples exhibited an expansion in the CeO2 lattice, demonstrating the successful doping of Bi3+, which has a cation radius (1.17 Å) larger than Ce4+ (0.97 Å). Moreover, the grain size listed in Table 1 indicates the basic grain size of ceria nanorods, which is composed by the oriented attachment of the cube-like basic grains with a [110] growth direction. Bi-doping significantly changes the grain sizes of CuCeO2−x nanorod catalysts and Bi/CuCeO2−x-2.5 shows the largest grain size. As reported in the literature [5], the ceria nanorod catalysts with larger basic grain size also shows much higher catalytic performance for CO-PROX, mainly attributed to the abundant oxygen vacancy and strong interaction between copper and ceria. It means that the basic grain size is not the key factor that determine the catalytic performance of the ceria-based catalysts. In addition, the N2 isotherms and their pore size distributions of CuCeO2−x, Bi/CuCeO2−x-5 and Bi/CuCeO2−x-7.5 (Fig. 1(d) and Table S1) were compared to explain the influence of Bi dopant on the texture property of copper-ceria nanorods catalysts. It can be seen that the SBET values of CuCeO2−x, Bi/CuCeO2−x-2.5 and Bi/CuCeO2−x-7.5 were respectively 63.1, 81.5 and 80.4 m2g−1, indicating that Bi doping could slightly increase the specific surface area of the catalysts and promote the high dispersion of CuOx species. The BJH pore size distribution of the catalysts demonstrates that the pore structure is also affected by the Bi doping, which leads to the reduced average pore size and larger pore volume. As the doping content of Bi reaches to 7.5%, a large portion of Bi elements might involve in the formation of Bi2O3 nanoparticles that dispersed on the surface of ceria nanorods (as identified by the following XPS spectra) with a slightly decreased SBET. The surface dispersed Bi species might cover the oxygen vacancy and hinder the interaction between copper and ceria interface, which adverse to the dispersion of copper species and leads to the increased crystal phase CuO. 3.2 XPS and UV-Raman of catalysts XPS spectra of CuCeO2−x and Bi/CuCeO2−x catalysts are given in Fig. 2(a-d) and their surface elements and valence distribution are shown in Table 2. The atomic ratio of Bi/(Bi+Cu+Ce) are 9.30 and 25.66 respectively for Bi/CuCeO2−x-2.5 and Bi/CuCeO2−x-7.5 catalysts. On account of that the detection depth of XPS is only 0.5–10 nm, the sharply increased surface content of Bi element in Bi/CuCeO2−x-7.5 indicates that a large portion of Bi elements are involved in the formation of Bi2O3 nanoparticles that dispersed on the surface of ceria nanorods, and only small amount of Bi3+ ions incorporate into the CeO2 lattice to form Ce-O-Bi solid solution in Bi/CuCeO2−x-7.5. Moreover, the larger copper content of Bi/CuCeO2−x-2.5 indicates the high dispersion of CuO species that strongly interacted with ceria support, which is also in accordance with XRD results. As shown in Fig. 2(a), two obvious peaks were detected at the position of 932.8–934.0 eV and 943.5 eV in the Cu 2p 2/3 XPS spectra, the former was the principal peaks of Cu 2p3/2 and the latter was the satellite peaks with shake-up structure [23,34]. It is obvious that the binding energy of Cu 2p3/2 shifts from 933.1 eV to 934.0 eV as 2.5% Bi doping in CuCeO2−x catalyst, which is attributed to the existence of highly dispersed CuO clusters with a portion of Cu2+ ions being unsaturated. The ratio of the intensity of the satellite peaks and the principal peaks (Isat/Ipp) could estimate the degree of the unsaturated Cu2+ ions and the lower Isat/Ipp indicates the higher degree of unsaturated Cu2+ ions. Compared with CuCeO2−x, Bi/CuCeO2−x-2.5 has a lower Isat/Ipp, which means the more unsaturated Cu2+ ions that caused by the stronger Cu-Ce interaction [6]. However, for Bi/CuCeO2−x-7.5, the Isat/Ipp value is slightly higher than that of Bi/CuCeO2−x-2.5, which is mainly resulted by the excessive Bi doping that dispersed on the surface of nanorod and impairs the copper-ceria interaction, as indicated by the surface Bi content. Fig. 2(b) is the Ce3d spectra of CuCeO2−x and Bi/CuCeO2−x catalysts. The u peak (900.60 eV), u’’ peak (907.50 eV), u’’’ peak (916.50 eV), v peak (882.00 eV), v’’ peak (889.10 eV), and v’’’ peak (898.00 eV) are attributed to Ce4+, while u′ peak (903.50 eV) and v′ peak (885.10 eV) are attributed to Ce3+ [23]. Compared with CuCeO2−x, the ratio of Ce3+/Ce for Bi/CuCeO2−x-2.5 is notably higher than the undoped catalyst. The higher ratio of Ce3+/Ce indicates the higher oxygen vacancy that is induced by the incorporation of Bi ions into ceria lattice, which contributes to promoting the oxygen mobility and improving the oxidation activity of the catalyst [35]. It can be seen that the Ce3+/Ce ratio of Bi/CuCeO2−x-7.5 is reduced than that of Bi/CuCeO2−x-2.5, which is as a consequence of the partial segregation of Bi species that dispersed on the surface of catalyst. As shown in Fig. 2(c) Two highly symmetric peaks present in Bi 4 f spectra, and the peak at 158.6 eV is related to Bi 4 f7/2 and that at 163.9 eV is related to Bi 4 f5/2 with spin-orbit separation of 5.3 eV, which is highly consistent with peaks of bismuth in the + 3 state in standard bismuth oxides [36,37]. The peak intensity of Bi 4 f in Bi/CuCeO2−x-7.5 are much larger than that in Bi/CuCeO2−x-2.5, indicating the higher doping amount of bismuth species. Fig. 2(d) shows the O1s spectrum, the Olatt peak (529.1 eV) belongs to the surface lattice oxygen, the Oads peak (531.2 eV) belongs to the surface adsorbed oxygen species and the Ov peak (530.4 eV) is ascribed to the surface oxygen vacancy. The ratio of Ov/(Olatt+Oads+Ov) indicates the surface oxygen vacancy concentration[38]. Notably, the ratio of Ov/(Olatt+Oads+Ov) in Bi/CuCeO2−x samples are significantly higher than the undoped CuCeO2−x catalyst, which indicates the important role of Bi doping in creating oxygen vacancy in ceria-related catalyst. These results demonstrate that doping optimal Bi elements could promote the substitution of Bi3+ ions to Ce4+ ions in the CeO2 lattice and form a solid solution structure, which causes the increased oxygen vacancy[29], which is also supported by the shift of the diffraction peaks in XRD diffractograms. Fig. 2(e) reveals the Raman spectra of CuCeO2−x, Bi/CuCeO2−x-2.5 and Bi/CuCeO2−x-7.5 nanorod catalysts. The Raman spectra of these three catalysts have obvious Raman peaks at 451 cm−1, which is the CeO2 fluorite structure characteristic vibration peak of F2 g vibration. The F2 g vibration peak value of CeO2 will shift due to the particle size inductive effect in the lattice caused by the disorder, doping or heating, or the existence of massive oxygen vacancy after CeO2 is reduced. And the change in oxygen vacancy concentration of CeO2 can be obtained by analyzing the shift of the Raman spectrum [39]. Compared with undoped CuCeO2−x nanorod catalyst, the F2 g peaks of Bi-doped CuCeO2−x nanorod catalysts move to the low-frequency band, which indicates that the symmetric stretching vibration of Ce[O]8 unit is distorted by Bi doping [40]. The ratio of A600/A451 of each sample is Bi/CuCeO2−x-2.5 (0.930) > CuCeO2−x (0.859) > Bi/CuCeO2−x-7.5 (0.682). The highest (A600/A451) value of Bi/CuCeO2−x-2.5 nanorod catalyst indicates that Bi3+enters the CeO2 lattice and weakens the Ce-O bond, which promotes the conversion of Ce4+ to Ce3+ and the formation of more oxygen vacancies. When the Bi dopant amount increases to 7.5%, the oxygen vacancy concentration of the catalyst is lower than that of the undoped CuCeO2−x nanorod catalyst, which is mainly caused by the partial segregation of Bi species that dispersed on the surface of catalyst and inhibits the formation of Ce-O-Bi solid solution. Generally, the existence of oxygen vacancy is beneficial to enhancing the mobility of lattice oxygen and Cu-Ce interaction. Therefore, doping appropriate amount of Bi in CuCeO2−x nanorods is able to promote the formation of oxygen vacancy and in favor to enhancing its catalytic performance in CO-PROX. 3.3 Redox properties and active oxygen species of catalysts To evaluate the redox properties of Bi-doped CuCeO2−x nanorod catalysts, Fig. 3 shows the H2-TPR and O2-TPD profiles of CuCeO2−x, Bi/CuCeO2−x-2.5 and Bi/CuCeO2−x-7.5 nanorod catalysts. As Fig. 3(a) shows, the catalysts have three reduction peaks (α, β and γ) between 100–300 ℃, which are respectively attributed to the reduction of highly dispersed CuO on the surface, the reduction of strongly bond Cu-[Ox]-Ce species that caused by the strong Cu-Ce interaction, and the reduction of bulk phase CuO [6,41]. The reduction temperatures and hydrogen consumptions of the reduction peaks are listed in Table 3. When an appropriate amount (2.5%) of Bi is doped into CuCeO2−x nanorod catalyst, the α peak and the β peak move to the low-temperature range with larger hydrogen consumptions. It indicates that the doped Bi species might enter the CeO2 lattice, causing the increase of lattice oxygen vacancy, which not only promotes the dispersion of CuOx species, but also enhance the formation of strongly bond Cu-[Ox]-Ce species (as also supported by XRD and Raman results) [11]. Compared with Bi/CuCeO2−x-7.5 nanorod catalyst, the α peak and β peak of Bi/CuCeO2−x-2.5 nanorod catalyst have lower temperature and larger hydrogen consumptions, indicating exceeded Bi dopant would decrease the redox property of Bi/CuCeO2−x. In addition, as shown in Fig. 3(b), two broad reduction peaks were related to the reduction of Ce4+ to Ce3+, one around 400–600 °C, associated to coordinately unsaturated surface capping oxygen, and a second peak around 700–900 °C, associated to reduction of bulk ceria that requires to be transported to the surface before their reduction. It can be seen that the reduction temperature of the surface lattice oxygen of ceria shifts from 503 °C to 473 and 485 °C respectively for Bi/CuCeO2-x-2.5 and Bi/CuCeO2-x-7.5. It indicates that Bi doping obviously reduced the reduction temperature of the surface lattice oxygen of ceria, and the optimum doping amount of Bi significantly accelerated the reducibility of Bi/CeO2-x nanorods support, which was attributed to the presence of more oxygen vacancy induced by the replacement of Bi3+ to Ce4+ in the CeO2 lattice. Fig. 3(c) presented the O2-TPD profiles in order to further demonstrate the effect of Bi doping on the formation of the active oxygen species. It can be seen that three desorption peaks are observed in these profiles: the first one (peak α) at 150–210 °C, which can be assigned to adsorbed molecular oxygen (adO2 -) on oxygen vacancies, and the second one (peak β) at 350–450 °C, which can be assigned to oxygen anion (O-), and the third one (peak γ) at 500–700 °C corresponding to atomic oxygen evolved from the bulk of CeO2 [42,43]. It is obvious that the surface density of oxygen vacancy estimated based on the amounts of adO2- follows the order: Bi/CuCeO2-x-2.5 > CuCeO2-x > Bi/CuCeO2-x-7.5. The largest amount of adO2- and the lowest peak temperature of peak α of Bi/CuCeO2-x-2.5 indicate the most higher surface density of oxygen vacancy and the oxygen in the gas phase could be activated and adsorbed onto Bi/CuCeO2-x-2.5 much easily. Moderate Bi doping increases the formation of lattice oxygen vacancy in CeO2, thereby promoting the interaction between copper oxide species. The excellent redox property would greatly promote the CO-PROX activity of the Bi/CuCeO2−x-2.5 nanorod catalyst. 3.4 Optical properties of catalysts To evaluate the influence of Bi dopant amount on the optical properties of CuCeO2−x nanorod catalysts, Fig. 4(a) shows the UV–vis-IR absorption spectrum of each catalyst. It can be seen that all catalysts have strong absorption in the range of 200–1200 nm, among them the Bi/CuCeO2−x-2.5 nanorod catalyst shows the strongest UV–vis absorption from 200 nm to 800 nm. The absorption intensity of Bi-doped CuCeO2−x nanorod catalysts in the IR range of 800 nm to 1200 nm decreases slightly but is higher than undoped CuCeO2−x nanorod catalysts in the range of 1300–2000 nm. Compared with the CuCeO2−x nanorod catalyst without doping Bi, the appropriate amount of Bi dopant enhances the UV–vis light response of the catalyst and increases the absorption of the UV–vis light bands [44]. The effective utilization of ultraviolet, visible and infrared energy in sunlight is increased, thus the photothermal conversion ability of the catalyst is enhanced, which benefits the higher surface temperature and CO oxidation ability of the catalyst under solar light irradiation. In Fig. 4(b), the optical band gaps (Eg) of the CuCeO2−x, Bi/CuCeO2−x-2.5 and Bi/CuCeO2−x-7.5 were calculated based on the Tauc Plot, and the results were approximately 2.77 eV, 2.50 eV and 2.47 eV, respectively. The narrower band gap means the catalyst is easier to absorb light. The results above indicate that Bi dopant could promote the formation of oxygen vacancy sites, which results in stronger light absorption ability [45]. The generation and separation efficiency of the photoinduced electron-hole pairs of CuCeO2−x and Bi/CuCeO2−x catalysts were also investigated by the on-off cyclic transient photocurrent experiment under full spectrum illumination, as shown in Fig. 4(c). It is obvious that the photocurrent intensity is significantly strengthened by Bi doping. The high photocurrent intensity of Bi/CuCeO2−x-2.5 and Bi/CuCeO2−x-7.5 indicates the efficient electron-hole separation and transfer process of these two catalysts under light illumination, which mainly caused by the enhanced oxygen vacancy that could efficiently promote the separation and interfacial transmission of photoexcited carriers [29]. Fig. S5 reveals the photoluminescence spectra of CuCeO2−x and Bi/CuCeO2−x-2.5. The emission peak around 385.3 nm is attributed to the charge transition from the Ce4f orbital to the O2p valence band [46]. We can see that CuCeO2−x exhibited an intensive PL peak due to the large recombination of the photogenerated charges. The photoluminescence peak intensity of Bi/CuCeO2−x-2.5 is significantly quenching, indicating that the doping Bi significantly increases the charge separation efficiency due to the oxygen vacancy that inhibits electron-hole recombination. 3.5 Catalytic performance evaluation of catalysts The CO conversion and O2 selectivity of the series Bi/CuCeO2-x catalyst for photothermal CO-PROX at 2.5 suns were exhibited in Fig. 5(a). It can be concluded that the sequence of CO conversion of Bi-doped CuCeO2−x nanorod catalysts in the CO-PROX reaction is Bi/CuCeO2−x-2.5 > Bi/CuCeO2−x-5 ≈ Bi/CuCeO2−x-7.5 > Bi/CuCeO2−x-1 ≈ CuCeO2−x. When the Bi dopant amount increases from 0% to 2.5%, the low-temperature catalytic performance of Bi/CuCeO2−x nanorod is significantly improved, the conversion of CO is increased from 81% to 90%, and the maximum surface temperature is up to 120 ℃. The photothermal CO-PROX performance of the catalyst is decreased significantly when the Bi dopant amount further increases to 7.5%. As Bi dopant amount increases from 0% to 7.5%, O2 selectivity of the series Bi/CuCeO2-x catalyst increases from 56% to 72% and then decreases to 56.8%. Bi/CuCeO2-x-2.5 catalyst shows much higher CO conversion and O2 selectivity than the other catalysts. As reported in literature [10], the decreased O2 selectivity is mainly caused by the competition oxidation of H2 with the CO oxidation. The higher CO conversion and O2 selectivity of Bi/CuCeO2-x-2.5 is mainly attributed to the following two reasons. The first one is that doping the optimum Bi element enhanced the formation of more oxygen vacancy that induces strong copper-ceria interaction, which benefits to the adsorption and activation of the CO and O2 molecular to participant to the oxidation reaction. And the other one is ascribed to the reduced band gap of ceria and lower combination of photogenerated electron-hole pairs that induced strong light absorption and higher photothermal conversion of Bi/CuCeO2-x-2.5 catalyst. It was also reported in the other literatures that the competition oxidation between CO and H2 exists in the thermal and photothermal CO-PROX of copper-ceria catalyst, and the O2 selectivity of Bi/CuCeO2-x-2.5 is comparable with that reported in the literature [47]. The above results show that doping the proper amount of Bi into the CuCeO2−x nanorods could help to promote the CO-PROX under light conditions, and excessive Bi dopant amount leads to the decline of CO-PROX performance. The decreased CO conversion in Bi/CuCeO2-x-7.5 could be attributed to the following reasons. On one hand, as the Bi doping amount reaches to 7.5%, from the N2-physysorption @ −196 °C and XRD, it is obvious that the SBET value of Bi/CuCeO2−x decreased with much more crystal phase CuO forming in the catalyst. The oxygen vacancy caused by the formation of Bi-O-Ce solid solution get decreased (indicated by the XRD, UV-Raman and XPS results), which mainly due to the segregation of Bi species on the surface of ceria nanorods in Bi/CuCeO2−x-7.5 and only a small amount of Bi entering the CeO2 lattice to form the solid solution. Caused by the above two reasons, the redox property and the copper-ceria interaction of Bi/CuCeO2−x become much weaken as indicated by the XPS and H2-TPR results, which is adverse to the catalytic activity for CO oxidation. On the other hand, the optical property of Bi/CuCeO2−x was also weakened by the over high Bi doping amount. The visible light absorption ability and separation efficiency of the photogenerated carriers of Bi/CuCeO2−x-7.5 is notably lower than that of Bi/CuCeO2−x-2.5 with much larger optical band gaps and lower photocurrent intensity than the latter. Therefore, ascribed to the above key factors, the 7.5% Bi doping in the CuCeO2−x catalyst results in a decrease in CO conversion. Fig. 5(b) shows the comparation of CO conversion and O2 selectivity of Bi/CuCeO2−x-2.5 for photothermal CO-PROX at different oxygen and CO concentrations. It can be seen that the CO conversion and O2 selectivity of Bi/CuCeO2−x-2.5 were significantly influenced by the oxygen and CO concentrations. As the ratio of oxygen and CO concentration increases from 1/2 to 2/1, on one hand, the O2 selectivity continues to increase from 37% to 98%, which is reasonable phenomenon that the adequate oxygen supply is beneficial for the selectivity oxidation of CO. On the other hand, the CO conversion first increase and then decrease, which is the highest at the reaction gas of 0.5%CO/0.5%O2/25%H2 +Ar. This result is mainly caused by the overhigh surface coverage of O2 or CO would both damage the CO oxidation activity of the Bi/CuCeO2−x-2.5 catalyst, and the optimum adsorption of O2 and CO molecules over the surface of catalyst is help of finishing the redox reaction. Fig. 6 shows comparation of CO conversion and O2 selectivity of Bi/CuCeO2−x-2.5 for photothermal CO-PROX with/without 7.5 vol% H2O in the reaction gas of 0.5%CO/0.5%O2/25%H2 +Ar. It is obvious that the addition of 7.5 vol% H2O significantly impairs the CO conversion but obviously increases the O2 selectivity of Bi/CuCeO2−x-2.5 for photothermal CO-PROX. It is reported in the literature [12] that the presence of adsorbed molecules water which blocks the active sites and leads to the negative effect of H2O to the CO conversion of copper-ceria catalyst during CO-PROX. The increased O2 selectivity with the addition of 7.5 vol% H2O is mainly due to the severely inhibition effect of H2O molecules for the H2 oxidation than CO oxidation, as a result of the increased O2 selectivity. Moreover, the result of the water resistance performance of Bi/CuCeO2−x-2.5 under different illumination intensity is also shown in Fig. 6. It is noticed that the CO conversion gradually increase and O2 selectivity becomes reduced along with the higher illumination intensity, and the catalytic performance maintains at the CO conversion of 85% and O2 selectivity of 65% under the illumination higher than 450 mW·cm−2, which indicates the unrecoverable catalytic performance caused by the block effect of water molecules on the active sites of the Bi/CuCeO2−x-2.5 catalyst. The long term photothermal catalytic stability of Bi/CuCeO2−x-2.5 has been tested and the result is shown in Fig. 7. It can be seen that the CO conversion maintains at 90% for 10 h without any degeneration. It indicates that Bi/CuCeO2−x-2.5 exhibits excellent photothermal stability in CO-PROX, which is mainly attributed to the high physicochemical stability of copper-ceria catalyst under the light illumination that has been reported by our previous work[23]. 4 Conclusion In the present work, a series of Bi/CuCeO2−x nanorod catalysts were synthesized with the co-precipitation hydrothermal and deposition-precipitation methods. The influence of Bi doping amount on the catalytic performance in photothermal CO-PROX in hydrogen-rich streams was mainly investigated. The structure and properties of the catalyst were analyzed by XRD, HRTEM, N2-physysorption @ −196 °C, H2-TPR, UV–vis-IR, photoluminescence spectrum, ICP, Raman and XPS. As the doping amount of Bi in the catalyst is 2.5%, the Bi/CuCeO2−x catalyst shows the best performance, and the conversion rate of CO reaches 90% in photothermal CO-PROX under 2.5 suns. Bismuth species are highly dispersed in the CeO2 lattice and Bi enters the CeO2 lattice to form Ce-O-Bi solid solution with abundant oxygen vacancy, promoting the catalytic activity in the CO-PROX. Moreover, Bi-doped CuCeO2−x nanorod catalyst has strong absorption in the whole solar spectrum. The Bi dopant enhances the light absorption ability and carrier separation of CuCeO2−x nanorod catalyst in the UV-Vis light bands, further promoting the photo-to-thermal conversion ability and the catalytic activity in photothermal CO-PROX. coredata.dc:description: The wide band gap of ceria limited the light absorption and photothermal conversion of copper-ceria catalyst for photothermal preferential oxidation of CO (CO-PROX). In the present work, doping Bi element was adopted to regulate the energy band and catalytic performance of CuCeO2−x nanorod catalysts for photothermal CO-PROX. Bi/CuCeO2−x nanorods were synthesized by co-precipitation hydrothermal and deposition precipitation method. The Bi/CuCeO2−x catalyst with the molar ratio of Bi/Ce 2.5% exhibited the best catalytic performance and the CO conversion reached 90% under 2.5 suns with a surface temperature of 120 °C. The doped Bi species were incorporated into the CeO2 lattice and promoted the formation of oxygen vacancy sites and the strong Cu-Ce interaction, as revealed by XRD, XPS, Raman and H2-TPR results. In addition, doping Bi reduced the band gap of ceria nanorod from 2.77 to 2.47 eV and remarkably enhanced the UV–vis light response and photogenerated carrier separation of Bi/CuCeO2−x-2.5.
coredata.dc:title: Bi-doped CuCeO2−x nanorod catalysts for photothermal CO-PROX in H2-rich streams: Enhanced oxygen vacancy and light absorption capacity
